comment.author: 23350042@N04
comment._content:
Private A Jones, was awared the Distinguished Conduct Medal. 

he was what?

comment.author: 69662531@N05
comment._content:
From the Commonwealth War Graves Commission website:

Name:JONES, ALFRED
Initials:A
Nationality:United Kingdom
Rank:Private
Regiment/Service:13th Hussars
Age:29
Date of Death:05/03/1917
Service No:9285
Awards:D C M
Additional information:Son of John Jones, of 55, Caerphilly Rd., Senghenydd, Cardiff, and the late Mary Jones.
Casualty Type:Commonwealth War Dead
Grave/Memorial Reference:XI. F. 15.
Cemetery:BAGHDAD (NORTH GATE) WAR CEMETERY

comment.author: 38811045@N04
comment._content:
Private Jones's regimental number dates to August 1912.

His DCM citation reads: "For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty.  He dressed a number of wounded men and carried them out of the firing line under heavy fire. He set a fine example to all ranks."

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38811045@N04]  thank you for helping expand private Jones's story by adding his citation details and the number information.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: INDEX of "The Thirteenth hussars in the great war", William Blackwood and Sons Edinburgh and London 1921 (on the Internet Archive) www.archive.org/stream/thirteenthhussar00dura/thirteenthh... has Jones, Pte., 270 Jones, Pte. Alfred, 178, 1S9, 340, 354, 363 where, on page 178, Alfred Jones' pal Lance-Corporal Watkins DCM describes the Fight at Lajj and coming across the mortally wounded private on March 5, 1917. Father's home, Senghenydd, is in Caerphilly which is 12 miles from Cardiff. Senghenydd is a Welsh mining town. It suffered Wales' worst mining disaster in 1913. Pte A. Jones, 13th Hussars - name on the Senghenydd War Memorial, Glamorgan www.roll-of-honour.com/Glamorgan/Senghenydd.html

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: The 1901 census shows that Alfred was born in Caerphilly. He had a 10yr old sister Rachel M Jones and an older one, Margaret J Jones aged 24. His father John was already a Widower, aged 48 and a Pit Stoker. They lived at 55 Caerphilly Road, Senghenydd. The houses still stand and a photograph of them features on the website dedicated to those who perished in the Universal Colliery disaster of 1913 www.senghenydd.net/senghenydd_now/row_of_houses_of_caerph...
